body:
Comment 1: 
I accept that this could potentially become an issue.

What's the best solution? We could create a whitelist of cacheable headers, but would
that negate the performance benefits of the memoization in the first place?

Removing the memoization makes the code almost 3x slower on direct cache hits (119 ns/op
to 355 ns/op for the string "accept-header"). Worth it?
_Owner changed to **r...@golang.org**._ _Status changed to **Accepted**._
